content: President Bush signed the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004, which included funding for transportation and election reform projects. The Act also included an across-the-board rescission of 0.59%. Congress passed a continuing resolution for FY2004 funding, extending funding for programs to January 31, 2004. The Senate passed its version of the FY2004 Transportation, Treasury and Independent Agencies Appropriation bill with a recommended $91.0 billion budget. The FY2004 Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriation bill passed by the House of Representatives included an additional $4.5 billion in highway funding, totaling $85.8 billion. Key differences from the Administration request were an extra $4.4 billion for highways and the removal of $3.4 billion for airport grants. This bill consolidated appropriations for the Department of Transportation and the Department of the Treasury into a single bill. The FY2004 Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriation bill underwent changes due to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security. This resulted in the reorganization of subcommittees in the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations. Various agencies were transferred to DHS, and budget numbers were adjusted for comparison. The House divides its appropriation bill into six titles, while the Senate has five titles. The FY2004 Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriation bill underwent changes due to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security, resulting in reorganization of subcommittees. The FY2003 Consolidated Appropriations Resolution included a 0.65% rescission for most accounts in the Department of Transportation and Department of the Treasury. The Administration's FY2004 budget request was $85.9 billion, $740 million below the final FY2003 figure. Total funding allocation within the request is shown in Table 2. The FY2004 Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriation bill underwent changes due to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security. During House deliberations on H.R. 2989, funding for two programs was struck on points of order, reducing total transportation funding in the bill. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 contains an across-the-board rescission of 0.59%. The FY2004 Transportation, Treasury, and Independent Agencies Appropriation bill underwent changes due to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security. The bill includes an across-the-board rescission of 0.59%, which is not reflected in the funding trends for transportation and treasury appropriations from FY1999-FY2004. Adjustments were made to the figures for Department of Transportation and Department of the Treasury appropriations for comparison purposes. The FY2004 Department of Transportation Appropriations request aligned with the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century and the Wendell Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act. The budget proposed changes to highway and transit funding structures in line with the Administration's reauthorization proposal. The request included a DOT budget of $54.3 billion, 2.6% below the FY2003 enacted level of $55.7 billion. The FY2004 Transportation-Treasury Appropriations bill figures differ from the Administration's totals due to offsets and funding actions. Funding for FAA's Grants-in-Aid to Airports and the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's Border Enforcement programs was struck during House deliberations, reducing total transportation funding in the bill. These figures reflect across-the-board rescissions and may not include all funding adjustments. The FY2004 Transportation-Treasury Appropriations bill includes additional funding for various programs such as the Essential Air Service program, Appalachian Development Highway System, motor carrier safety activities, and NHTSA. Congress also postponed Amtrak's loan repayment and there are $14 million in permanent appropriations. Total resources for RSPA in FY2003 were $119 million, and total funding for FY2004 is $132 million. The FY2004 Transportation-Treasury Appropriations bill provides additional funding for various programs. The majority of the funding is allocated for Operations & Maintenance expenses, with no major new initiatives proposed. The FY2004 Transportation-Treasury Appropriations bill provides additional funding for various programs, with the FAA receiving $13.93 billion, an increase of $440 million from FY2003. The majority of the funding is allocated for Operations & Maintenance expenses, with no major new initiatives proposed. The FY2004 Transportation-Treasury Appropriations bill provides $13.93 billion for the FAA, with a focus on Operations & Maintenance expenses. The funding split between trust fund and general fund contributions has been a key part of the annual FAA budget debate. The FY2004 Act includes $7.5 billion for Operations & Maintenance and $2.91 billion for Facilities and Equipment. The majority of O&M funding is for air traffic control, certification, and safety-related activities, while F&E funding saw a slight decrease from the previous year. The FY2004 Transportation-Treasury Appropriations bill provides $13.93 billion for the FAA, with a focus on Operations & Maintenance expenses. Unobligated F&E funds of $30 million are subject to rescission in P.L.108-199. F&E funding is used primarily for capital investment in air traffic control and safety. P.L. 108-199 expends $119.4 million on RE&D, slightly more than the Senate proposal. The EAS program receives funding from designated user fees and had $102 million provided in FY2003. The FY2004 Act provides $102 million for the Essential Air Service (EAS) program, with $50 million from regular authorization and $52 million from the aviation trust fund. It rejects the Bush Administration's proposal to reduce the program size and require local contributions. The Act also excludes a pilot cost-sharing program and a provision for community reporting on program coordination and funding improvement. The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) is allocated $3.4 billion, similar to the previous year. The FY2004 budget proposal requested $3.4 billion for AIP, with the House recommending $3.425 billion. The House-passed bill did not include funding for AIP, but the Senate-passed bill provided $3.5 billion, including a $100 million transfer from the facilities and equipment account. The bill prioritized projects at 241 airports and prohibited using AIP grants for certain airport improvements. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 provides $3.4 billion for AIP, prohibiting certain airport improvements. The FHWA budget funds the Federal-Aid Highway Program. The President requested $30.2 billion for FHWA in FY2004, a decrease of $2.2 billion. The President requested $30.2 billion for FHWA in FY2004, a decrease of $2.2 billion from the previous year. The proposed budget included a new $1.0 billion Infrastructure Performance and Maintenance initiative, aimed at funding "ready-to-go" projects to address congestion and improve infrastructure conditions. Additionally, there were proposed changes reflecting the Administration's surface transportation reauthorization proposal. The House and Senate passed FY2004 appropriations bills for FHWA, with the House bill providing $34.6 billion and the Senate bill providing $34.8 billion. Both bills included provisions to redirect gasohol excise tax revenues to the highway trust fund, adding roughly $600 million in revenue. Earmarking of funds for federal-aid highway discretionary programs continued in both bills. The enacted Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 provides $34.7 billion in total budgetary resources for FHWA, slightly higher than the House total and slightly lower than the Senate total. This represents an increase of over 6% from FY2003 and over 12% from the Administration's budget request. The bill heavily earmarks discretionary programs, directing $175 million for surface transportation projects. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 earmarks funds for various transportation programs under FHWA, including core formula programs that were traditionally left free of earmarks. Over $1 billion of unobligated core program funds are earmarked for specific projects, with the federal share being 100%. Funding is drawn from state's distributed core program funds or STP funds distribution, and projects not eligible under core programs are funded from STP funds. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 provides a 100% federal share for earmarked projects, a departure from past practices. Nearly $300 million unobligated core formula funds are allocated for interagency transfers and project earmarks, including funds for the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Additionally, $150 million is allocated for the Appalachian Development Highway System, with $75 million earmarked for specific projects. TEA-21 Funding Framework, set to expire in 2003, was extended to 2004. It maintained existing transportation programs and funding. The largest surface transportation program in U.S. history, TEA-21 mostly continued highway and transit programs from its predecessor legislation. Major federal-aid highway programs include NHS, IM, STP, BRR, and CMAQ. The TEA-21 Funding Framework, extended to 2004, continued existing transportation programs like NHS, IM, STP, BRR, and CMAQ. Highway funding includes apportioned, exempt, and allocated programs controlled by FHWA or other entities. FMCSA, created in 1999, took over responsibilities on January 1, 2000. FMCSA became operational on January 1, 2000, taking over responsibilities from DOT's Office of Motor Carrier Safety. It issues and enforces federal motor carrier safety regulations for interstate commercial truck and bus operations, administers grants for state safety programs, conducts inspections of Mexican-domiciled drivers and vehicles entering the US, and reviews carriers. Funding for FMCSA activities comes mainly from the federal Highway Trust Fund, with an FY2004 budget request of $447 million, a 43% increase from FY2003. The FY2004 budget for FMCSA was $447 million, a significant increase from the previous year. The appropriation included funds for administrative expenses, motor carrier safety grants, and various other programs. The budget for administrative and operations expenses was set at $176 million, with a focus on enforcement, outreach, and the establishment of a medical review board to assist FMCSA. The FY2004 budget for FMCSA included funds for administrative expenses, personnel compensation, outreach efforts, and grants for the Motor Carrier Safety Assistance Program. The House approved $190 million, the Senate approved $237 million, and the final agreement was $190 million. These funds support state enforcement of commercial vehicle safety regulations and cover up to 80% of program costs. The FY2004 budget for FMCSA included funds for administrative expenses, personnel compensation, outreach efforts, and grants for the Motor Carrier Safety Assistance Program. The Senate bill allocated an additional $47 million for construction of border inspection stations for trucks. The conference agreement for FY2004 includes $170 million for MCSAP, $20 million for information systems and safety initiatives, and $111.5 million for various initiatives such as southern border inspection facilities, operations grants, and CDL improvement grants. NHTSA funding supports programs to improve traffic safety by reducing impaired driving, increasing occupant protection, improving police traffic services, enhancing emergency medical responses to crashes, ensuring compliance with federal vehicle safety regulations, and addressing emerging vehicle safety problems. The Administration requested $665 million for NHTSA in FY2004, an increase of $231 million from FY2003. $447 million was designated for traffic safety grants to states, focusing on occupant protection and impaired driving, while $218 million was for NHTSA's operations and research activities to reduce highway fatalities and prevent injuries. Funding areas included research, highway safety programs, and analysis of crash statistics and vehicle performance. The House, Senate, and conference agreement recommend funding for NHTSA and FRA in FY2004. NHTSA's funding includes $225 million for highway traffic safety grants and $222.5 million for operations and research. FRA's funding is mainly for Amtrak, with $900 million requested by the Administration. The House agreed to $900 million, the Senate to $1.346 billion, and P.L. 108-199 provides $1.225 billion for Amtrak. The Senate, House, and P.L. 108-199 agreed on funding amounts for railroad safety and operations. The President requested increases in funding for railroad safety and research, with the House, Senate, and P.L. 108-199 providing varying amounts. The FRA budget debate focuses on Amtrak, agency safety activities, Next Generation High-Speed Rail, and state funding for high-speed rail initiatives. The Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) is the primary agency responsible for promoting and regulating railroad safety. The proposed budget for FRA's safety program in FY2004 is $131.2 million, representing a 13% increase from the previous year. The funds are used for salaries, travel, training, and monitoring safety performance in the rail industry. The goals include reducing rail accidents, grade-crossing accidents, and hazardous materials incidents. Funding authority for the program expired in FY1998, and the railroad safety statute was last reauthorized in 1994. The Federal Railroad Administration's safety program funding expired in FY1998, and the railroad safety statute was last reauthorized in 1994. Despite hearings since 1994, there has been no agreement on funding for FRA's regulatory activities. FRA conducts research on topics like employee fatigue and train movement control. The FY2003 DOT appropriation provided $29.1 million for research, with a $35 million request for FY2004. The House Committee recommended $28.2 million for research activities. The House Committee recommended $28.2 million for research activities, while the Senate Committee recommended $34.2 million. The conferees settled on $34 million. The Next Generation High-Speed Rail R&D program focuses on high-speed train control systems, track technology, corridor planning, and locomotives. The Administration requested $23.2 million for FY2004, with the House agreeing to $28.3 million and the Senate to $29.3 million. The President requested $900 million, below Amtrak's FY2003 appropriation. Amtrak stated it could not survive on $900 million, and the DOT Inspector General agreed. The House and Administration agreed to $900 million, while the Senate approved $1.346 billion. P.L. 108-199 provided $1.225 billion for Amtrak, with additional provisions for funding structure and route requirements. P.L. 108-199 directs the Secretary of Transportation to establish a competitive bidding procedure for state-supported routes currently operated by Amtrak. States can contract with non-Amtrak operators for service, with the option to use Amtrak's equipment and services if needed. The Secretary has the power to compel Amtrak to provide equipment and services if terms cannot be agreed upon. Congress began stipulating in FY2003 that Amtrak's appropriation would go through the Secretary of Transportation, reducing Amtrak's discretion with federal funding. Amtrak was required to submit a 5-year business plan to Congress in 2003. Amtrak submitted a plan to Congress in 2003 requesting $1.6 billion annually for maintenance and addressing backlogged needs. Two bills aim to reauthorize Amtrak with funding of $2 billion annually for three to six years. Various proposals seek to restructure federal passenger rail policy, including shifting responsibility to states. Sen. Hollings and others have proposed a plan for restructuring Amtrak and passenger rail service, authorizing $2 billion annually for 6 years for Amtrak operations and $48 billion in bonds for capital improvements. MARAD's mission is to promote the development of a U.S. merchant marine capable of carrying domestic and foreign commerce, and to serve as a naval and military auxiliary in times of war. MARAD administers programs benefiting U.S. vessel owners, shipyards, and crews. The budget for FY2004 requested $219 million, with $226.4 million provided in the Consolidated Appropriations Act. The focus is on the Maritime Guaranteed Loan Program, which provides loans for purchasing ships and modernizing shipyards. The Administration requested no funds for additional loans in FY2004 but asked for $4.5 million for existing loan administration. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2003 initially provided $4 million for administrative expenses for the Title XI program, but later $25 million was allocated in the Wartime Supplemental Appropriations bill. The DOT Inspector General recommended MARAD to improve loan application reviews and financial oversight after the bankruptcy of American Classic Voyages. The General Accounting Office also identified weaknesses in the program and suggested improvements for financial oversight. The conference agreement highlights MARAD's cooperation with the IG's office for management reforms in the Title XI program. The Administration requested $104.4 million for operations and training, with specific allocations for the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, state maritime academies, and MARAD operations. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provides $107 million for operations and training. The Administration also requested funding for the Maritime Security Program (MSP) and the disposal of obsolete vessels in the National Defense Reserve Fleet (NDRF). MARAD has until 2006 to dispose of surplus ships with environmental concerns. The Consolidated Appropriations Act provides $16.2 million for ship disposal. The Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA) includes various entities and conducts transportation safety activities with a budget request of $118 million for FY2004. The Administration proposed $67 million for RSPA's pipeline transportation safety program and $25 million for hazardous materials transportation safety in FY2004. Additional funding was requested to enhance RSPA's oversight of hazardous materials transportation regulations and safety of containment systems for nuclear fuel. The House approved $111.3 million for RSPA, with $23.6 million for hazardous materials safety and $64.1 million for pipeline safety. The Department of the Treasury received funding for various functions, including economic policies, financial services for the government, law enforcement, and production of currency. The creation of the Department of Homeland Security in 2002 led to changes in its responsibilities. The Department of the Treasury serves as the federal government's economic policymaker, financial manager, and revenue collector. It consists of departmental offices and operating bureaus, with financial responsibilities handled by various bureaus and law enforcement duties carried out by specific agencies. The Department of the Treasury oversees financial management, revenue collection, and law enforcement agencies such as the U.S. Secret Service, IRS, and Customs Service. The establishment of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) transferred some agencies from the Treasury Department to DHS, reducing the Treasury's law enforcement involvement. The Treasury Department also created the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau to handle alcohol and tobacco tax collection and regulation previously managed by BATF. The Bush Administration requested $11.408 billion in funding for the Treasury Department in FY2004. The Bush Administration requested $11.408 billion in funding for the Treasury Department in FY2004, with top priorities including bolstering IRS efforts to enforce tax laws, improving efficiency, combating money laundering, and supporting international efforts. The proposed budget allocated funds mainly to IRS, Financial Management Service, Bureau of Public Debt, and Departmental Offices. Additional funding was requested for FinCen and the International Technical Assistance program. The Administration proposed merging TIGTA with OIG due to transferred functions. The House Committee approved $11.273 billion for Treasury operations in FY2004, $70 million less than requested. H.R. 2989 allocated less funding for IRS operations but more for departmental offices. The House approved increased funding for Treasury departmental offices in FY2004, with a significant portion going towards administrative costs related to personnel transfers. H.R. 2989 also allocated additional funds for specific offices within the Treasury, denied the proposal to merge OIG and TIGTA, and approved funding for FinCen in FY2004. The bill passed in the House with amendments, including one reducing funding for an IRS pilot program. The House rejected an amendment to divert $75 million from an IRS pilot program for earned income tax credit compliance to programs for business taxpayers. Another amendment aimed to prevent the Treasury Department from using funds to assist in overturning a judicial ruling in the Cooper v. IBM case regarding age discrimination in pension plans. The House passed an amendment with a vote of 258 to 160, endorsing funding levels for Treasury departmental offices and operating bureaus. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a bill providing $11.196 billion for the Treasury Department in FY2004, $202 million more than FY2003 but less than the Bush Administration's request. The difference in funding was mainly due to smaller budgets for IRS operations, including tax processing and information systems. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a bill (S. 1589) that would have merged IRS accounts for tax law enforcement and the earned income tax credit compliance program, resulting in a drop in funding for the initiative in FY2004. The bill also allocated additional funding for Treasury's departmental offices, with increases for the Office of International Affairs and the Office of Terrorist Finance and Financial Crimes. Additionally, the bill opposed the proposed merger of the OIG and TIGTA, recommending separate funding increases for both entities in FY2004. The Senate approved funding for FinCen of $6.1 million to manage new responsibilities under the USA Patriot Act. The Senate also passed amendments related to Treasury appropriations, including a study on pre-certifying eligibility for the EITC and an amendment by Sen. Tom Harkin. The Senate passed an amendment by Sen. Tom Harkin to prevent the Treasury Department from implementing a new regulation allowing companies to convert pension plans. Differences in appropriations for the Treasury Department between the Senate and House versions of H.R. 2989 were related to funding for IRS operations. A conference was agreed upon to resolve the differences, resulting in a total funding of $11.166 billion for Treasury Department operations in FY2004. This amount was $317 million more than FY2003, but less than the amounts requested and approved by the Bush Administration, House, and Senate. Funding for the IRS accounted for 92% of total Treasury appropriations in FY2004. The Treasury Department received $11.166 billion in funding for FY2004, with the IRS accounting for 92% of the total appropriations. The IRS administers various taxes and fees for the federal government, including income taxes, social insurance taxes, and estate and gift taxes. In FY2002, the IRS collected $2,017 billion before refunds, with individual income tax revenue being the largest component at $1,038 billion. The Bush Administration requested $10.436 billion for IRS operations in FY2004, a 6.1% increase from the previous year. The FY2004 budget for IRS was 6.1% greater than FY2003 at $9.834 billion. $4.135 billion was allocated for processing, assistance, and management; $4.086 billion for tax law enforcement; $1.709 billion for information systems; $500 million for BSM; $251 million for EITC compliance; and $35 million for health insurance tax credit administration. Enforcement initiatives included a pilot program for EITC certification and hiring private collection agents for unpaid taxes. $133 million was set aside to combat tax evasion. The Administration proposed a new program to curb tax evasion by targeting various sources, including abusive tax schemes, misuse of trusts, and under-reporting of income. They projected a 72% increase in audits for high-income individuals and businesses. Concerns were raised about the funding for IRS operations, overseen by the IRS Oversight Board, which reviews the annual budget request and makes recommendations to Congress. The IRS Oversight Board recommended a budget of $10.724 billion for FY2004, higher than the Bush Administration's request. They also suggested hiring 2,120 full-time employees to improve tax law compliance. The Board aimed to achieve a 2% real growth rate, allocate more resources to the BSM, and restore funds for customer service and enforcement. The House Committee on Appropriations passed a measure providing $10.352 billion for the IRS in FY2004, $85 million less than the Bush Administration's request. The funding was allocated to various accounts including processing, assistance, and management; tax law enforcement; information systems; and business systems modernization. The Committee's report highlighted IRS programs for low-income taxpayers. The House overwhelmingly passed H.R. 2989 on September 9, 2003, endorsing recommended funding levels for IRS accounts in FY2004. The bill included funding for low-income taxpayer clinics, tax counseling for elderly taxpayers, the Free-File Alliance, the earned income tax credit program, and hiring private collection agencies for overdue taxes. An amendment adopted by the House prevented funds from being used to overturn a federal judge's ruling on age discrimination in IBM's pension plan. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved $10.276 billion in funding for IRS operations in FY2004, with specific allocations for processing, tax law enforcement, information systems, BSM, and administration. The Senate Appropriations Committee approved $10.276 billion in funding for IRS operations in FY2004. The Committee report praised IRS programs for the elderly and low-income taxpayers, recommending specific funding levels. The Senate passed the measure by a vote of 93 to 1, making no changes. The Senate passed version of H.R. 2989 made no changes to the funding for IRS operations in FY2004 approved by the Appropriations Committee. Two amendments were approved related to the IRS, one preventing the Treasury Department from using funds for a new IRS regulation, and the other requiring a study on a pilot program for EITC certification. The House version of H.R. 2989 provided $76 million more in funding for the IRS for FY2004, distributed among processing, enforcement, and information systems accounts. The House and Senate agreed on a conference to resolve funding differences for the IRS in FY 2004. The total funding would be $10.245 billion, with allocations for processing, assistance, tax law enforcement, information systems, and health insurance tax credit administration. The agreement included specific allocations for programs like Tax Counseling for the Elderly and low-income taxpayer clinics. The conference agreement on H.R. 2989 included a reduction of $39 million in approved amounts for the IRS, reflecting congressional dissatisfaction with program results and distrust of IRS managers. It also prohibited the IRS from using funds to lift a 1999 moratorium on converting pension plans to cash-balance plans, requiring proposed legislation for transition relief instead. Additionally, the IRS was mandated to submit a final report to Congress by June 30, 2005, examining aspects of any certification program established by the agency. The final report on the IRS certification program for EITC eligibility was included in a consolidated appropriations bill (H.R. 2673) with an across-the-board spending cut. The House and Senate approved the conference report, and President Bush signed it into law as P.L. 108-199. The appropriations for the United States Postal Service were detailed in Table 7 of the bill. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 includes an across-the-board rescission of 0.59%. The U.S. Postal Service generates most of its funding through product sales, but also receives appropriations for specific services. Congress is required to reimburse USPS $29 million annually until 2035 for services provided in the 1990s. In FY2003, USPS received a revenue forgone appropriation of $59.6 million, including $30.8 million for FY2003 and $29 million annually under the Revenue Forgone Reform Act of 1993. The Administration proposed $55.7 million for FY2004 and $29 million for FY2003. USPS also had $31 million for FY2002. The Treasury and General Government Appropriations bill funds most offices in the Executive Office of the President, except for three.
